REUNION

   (Fiction)

   (By: DHIMAN PR)

(A translation of the story ‘Punrmilan’ in Hindi language)

They both – Rajni and her son Anant – used to eat together, play together and study together. Truly speaking, they were less mother and son but were more friends. The age of Rajni was about forty years while Anant was fifteen years old. Anant, a roly-poly boy of fair complexions, tall structure and dashing looks, came from a business community of Punjab State. Rajni’s husband, Gurnam was running a garage, where not only he repaired the defective cars, rather dealt in sale-purchase of old cars too. Almost fifteen workers, including an Accountant, a Supervisor, Mechanics, Assistant Mechanics, and Assistants dealing with sale-purchase of cars, used to work in his workshop-cum-office every day. Gurnam himself supervised performance of all workers minutely and believed satisfaction of customers as his foremost duty. Consequently, they were financially well off. The responsibility of running the household was on Rajni. She did not keep her fist closed for good food and good clothing, though she was a disciplined lady who would not tolerate any wasteful expenditure. Therefore, she even refused to agree with the improper demands of Anant. 

Often, man is bad by nature. He is not pleased seeing others well-nourished. And if he is from the same profession, remains jealous always, and makes all endeavors to fail him. This all was happening with Gurnam too, although unaware of all such things, he was always busy in his duty.

It is said that the abominable sight of a person can be negative and even horrible. It was like this that happened with Gurnam and his family. One evening when, after the day’s work, he was coming from workshop to home in his car, he was collided by a fast-arriving truck from opposite side, and died on the spot.

All family-members and relatives came, condoled Rajni and assured her to always stand by her side for whatever help she would need. But all this could not bring Gurnam back!

Rajni was in shock, and Anant – his condition was deplorable due to crying all the time. Rajni could imagine Anant’s as well as her own future in dark. But then came all workers in the garage together and assured her that they would continue to work with the same zeal and honesty as they were working in front of their late master. Rajni too decided with a heavy heart to herself look after the work of the garage and would sit there for two hours in the morning and two hours in the evening every day.

The family members and relatives returned to their places after the formalities of thirteen days were complete, and thereafter none turned to see how Rajni and Anant were living, not to say of extending the helping hand towards them. Perhaps it is the custom of time.

Every day, Rajni went to garage, saw each and every work being done for herself, as also kept an account of income. Although it was not an easy task to look after both household and business together yet, as a brave lady, she left no stone unturned to do justice with both of them.

Gurnam had a different destiny, as if Rajni, her son and all workers in the garage were fed by his destiny. All workers were working hard and honestly as earlier, even more than that, but number of customers was constantly falling down. Slowly, the number of workers had to be reduced, and then the day came when she had to close down the garage. Family members and relatives knew everything but were unknown.

Yes! Some relatives and family members did come but less to share Rajni’s pain, more to persuade her to re-marry with one of their relatives. This was not at all acceptable to Rajni. She believed that had there been comforts of husband in her destiny, Gurnam would not have died. She was also worried for Anant and was of the view that the re-marriage would put the future of Anant in dark. So, she totally rejected all such proposals, making the proposers angry as they stopped conversation with her.

Now Rajni was perturbed with regard to Anant’s and her own living. Though, the home they were living in was their own, and she had good deposits with her and in the bank yet there are hundred types of expenditure in the household. Above all, Anant was studying in the best and the costliest school of the city. Even the oceans get dry if not re-charged by the rivers-waters, it was only an ordinary home. 

Rajni was not unaware of this fact. She had proficiency in stitching work, and so she began stitching of ladies’ suits. The profession was successful and she opened a boutique in her home itself. Now, she was having many ladies to assist her in stitching as well as in sale. God had returned the old days to her except Gurnam.

The people were jealous again but ignorant of all this, Rajni was busy in her work. She would rise early morning and after taking bath, prepared breakfast and lunch for Anant’s school. By that time, Anant would also be ready, and after feeding him, she would take him for boarding the school bus. Coming back home, she would take her own breakfast and proceed to the boutique. She would accompany Anant to the park in the evening, where he would be busy playing with his friends while Rajni conversed with other women. Thereafter, would return home with Anant, prepare dinner, help him in doing home-work, told good stories infusing high values in him. This was her daily routine.

The games of nature are strange. Nobody knows, when it has an auspicious sight and when an enraged look. That evening was the furious form of nature. Like every day, she with Anant went to the park happily, where Anant started playing with his friends and Rajni talking to other ladies. It was dusk and time to go back. Children were coming back after play but Anant was nowhere to be seen.

Rajni inquired about Anant from his friends. With what they told made her shocked and frightened, as she was not able to stand properly and was feeling dizzy. His friends told that when they all were playing, two strangers came into the park and inquired about ‘Tulsi’ ward. Anant told them that one can reach there in ten minutes’ walk. But the strangers said that they had been searching the place with the help of google map for the last one hour in their car but could not be able to locate it. They said that they would be grateful if any of us would take them there, and they would drop him back in the park in their car. We were all ready to accompany but they chose Anant to go with them. As he did not come back to the park, we thought that he would have gone home, and aunty, he must be in the home. Let us go and see him there.

All of them arrived at Anant’s residence hurriedly but found the house locked. The children searched him here and there and he was nowhere to be seen. Rajni’s heart was filling with suspicions, she was apprehending some no-good issue. There was no other option but to wait. The mind is highly active – sometimes it frightens but assures the next moment – be courageous, he would come.

The message was gone to Rajni’s brother and near relatives. Next morning all came. Rajni was in a bad condition by constant weeping. She got fits repeatedly. Her sister-in-law (brother’s wife) was looking after her sitting by her side, and solacing that Anant would come in a day or two. Rajni’s heart was saying the same thing too.

A report was lodged with the police station, and enquiries began. There was no clue of Anant even after three days. The teardrops in Rajni’s eyes were dried up. Her mind was in suspicion that Anant was not alive but the next moment her heart would sound, “No, it’s not like that. He is the son of a brave father; he would never do a cowardly act”. Whatever it might be, but all were unanimous in thinking that he was trapped in some serious problem, may Wahe Guru help him.

Months elapsed, there was no trace of Anant. Her brother and other relatives had gone back to their places but her sister-in-law preferred to stay with her.

Boutique was closed, Rajni was in depression, she had no appetite. Sister-in-law forcibly fed him a little. Brother had a good business; he was sending money to meet house-hold expenses regularly.

There was a little time left in completion of one year. Rajni persuaded her sister-in-law to go back to her brother and now she was totally alone. Seldom women from her neighborhood came to talk to her, or Anant’s friends came and asked if anything was to be bought from the market, and brought whatever was told.

One year had elapsed. Rajni went too weak, her body-frame was not as it was earlier and she had lost her aura. She had no wish to eat or to sit with anyone, nor to talk. She often thought that she was deprived both of her husband as also her son, and what for to live now. But the heart would console, “Why are you doing lunatic deeds? Anant is not dead; he is live and would come soon to end all your sorrows and sufferings”. This not only solaced her but inspired her to live for her son.

Sometimes, she thought, “Let him come, I’ll beat him so much with a stick that he would never go like this again. Her heart would interfere, “Don’t be insane, what was his fault? He did not go at his own. Beating him is not a wise act, rather offer him good and delicious dishes and keep him happy by all means on his arrival”.

Thought again – now he is sixteen years old. I’ll look for a beautiful bride after some time of his coming back and would marry him, and dreamt of the jewelry and dresses for both - bride and groom.

To tell story of the other side, the strangers after getting Anant sit in their car, proceeded further. While Anant was narrating the way to Tulsi ward, he lost his consciousness. When he regained advertency, he found himself lying down on a bed in a big hospital. The dress and the language of people there were different, Anant could not understand what they spoke. He was terribly scared, and had a feeling to cry but somehow restrained himself in fear.

Luckily, a man named Mohammad Hussain from Punjab State in Pakistan was working in that hospital. He had been living in the city for the last ten years. He could understand and speak the language of the people there. He got an impression that Anant was from Punjab State in India. While Hussain could not understand Hindi language well, both of them were capable of speaking and understanding Gurumukhi language.

Hussain told Anant that the latter was under treatment in a renowned ‘City Hospital’ in Dubai city in United Arab Emirates, and that he had been found lying down in unconscious condition outside the hospital early morning a week ago. He was quickly brought to the hospital and the police was informed. His pulse and heart rate were too slow and he was very week as if he could not get sumptuous and nutritious food for years together, and that he had been given a very high dose of anesthetic drug. After the police came in action, his treatment was started. As the unconsciousness was very deep, it took a full week’s time for Anant to come out of it.

Anant began to cry after hearing this. Finding a father like hand of Hussain on his head, his cry changed into sobbing. After Hussain’s consolation and assurance of helping him time and again, Anant talked about him while sniveling and felt concerned about his mother. He said, “Two strangers made me sit in their car to tell way to a ward in his city. It seems that I had lost consciousness in the car itself. When regained mindfulness, I found myself in a dark cell. Perhaps they wanted to sell me for a good money for which they brought customers even. Many of the customers did not accept me saying that I was a child, while others refused to pay the amount of money they quoted for my exchange. For I was not being sold, they beat me severely, gave too less to eat and did not allow me to come out of that dark cell. Once, I heard them talking that police were searching for me everywhere and nobody knows when the situation would be normal. I also heard them conversing among themselves that there was no customer for me in that place, as such I would have to be taken to some other country for sale – perhaps they were discussing the name of this country itself. I don’t know for how many days I lived in their custody but it looks that it must be a very long spell of time. Narrating this, he again began to weep remembering his mother back in India.”

It was obvious that the strangers were not gentle persons, rather they seemed to be members of a child thief gang. Hussain encouraged him that he would talk to the owner of the hospital and request him to arrange for your home going in your country. Anant seemed to be satisfied to some extent.

That hospital was owned by one Rashid Bhai, who was the richest Sheikh of the city. He had many oil wells too. Now, he had grown old and as such all his business was being looked after by his two young sons, who used to honor him too much.

Hussain met Rashid Bhai in his home in the evening and briefed him about the story of Anant. Rashid Bhai heard patiently and asked Hussain to come with the boy next morning.

Next morning, Hussain reached Rashid Bhai with Anant. As they reached there, Anant burst into tears. After all he was a child!

Rashid Bhai was satisfied. He gave a ring to the police station and inquired about Anant’s case. He was informed that inquiries were under way and a breakthrough was expected any time. Rashid Bhai then called his younger son, Yunus and briefed him about Anant. He asked Yunus to take Anant to the Indian Embassy and request them to make arrangements for his return to his country.

Like his father, Yunus too was a gentle and social person with a helping hand. He took Anant to the Indian Embassy and narrated the entire story relating to Anant. The staff of the Embassy talked to Anant and took an application duly signed by him and verified by Yusuf. They said that the application would be forwarded to India for inquiries. On completion of enquiry, if everything was found correct, arrangements would be made to send Anant to India. It would take two to three months to complete the process. A slight smile was noticed on the face of Anant after a long time.

Yunus Bhai decided to keep Anant at their home till he was sent to India. And it is true that the family of Rashid Bhai provided all facilities to him thinking as if he was the youngest addition in the family. New clothes were got stitched for him besides meeting his other needs. In the meanwhile, they posted two letters to Anant’s mother but probably the letters did not reach her as there was no reply from the other side. Now, Anant found himself to be somewhat familiar with the family members of Rashid Bhai as he would help them in their domestic affairs and serve personal needs of Rashid Bhai. Anant could now understand and speak their language a little bit.

The enquiry report came from India after two months and that was in favor of Anant. So, the documents to send him back to India were being prepared in the Embassy, which would likely to take another fifteen days’ time.

In the meantime, though the report of loss of Anant was registered in the concerned police station in his city in India yet the policemen visited his home in connection with the inquiry from the Indian Embassy in United Arab Emirates, and told his mother that Anant was live and would come back shortly.

The delights of Rajni knew no bounds. Message was sent to all relatives. First of all, Rajni went to Gurudwara, bowed her head and thanked Wahe Guru. Thereafter, she made herself busy in making sweets and other dishes in pure ghee for Anant. Cleaning was done in the entire house; all articles were kept neatly and systematically. The house got a new look.

Noval ideas came into the mind of Rajni every day. Sometimes, she thought that Anant was now sixteen years old, he would have attained a good health. But the next moment another idea coruscated - don’t know where he would have stayed, what got to eat in such a long spell of time, how attained a good health!

She sometimes thought of his marriage, then an idea flashed into her mind, “He is still sixteen years old – I’ll make arrangements for his studies and make him able for some occupation. What is hurry for his marriage, let him marry a girl of his choice himself when the time would come”.

Sometimes talked to herself, “Let him come, first of all I’ll reprimand him like anything, beat him. What was the necessity for him to sit in their car?” Then thought, how did he know about their intentions, he only extended a helping hand to them which was his duty.

Sometimes tears came out from her eyes for no reason, and seldom she performed different forms of dance in happiness. She was in bizarre state of health.

Meanwhile, Dubai police caught those members of the child thief gang who left Anant outside the hospital in an unconscious condition and ran away. They had confessed to have picked up Anant from India for the purpose of sale. Anant too had identified them. They were put to jail.

The documents and an air ticket to go from Dubai to India were delivered to Anant by the Indian Embassy. He was to fly next week. Rashid Bhai and his family members gave Anant adequate Indian currency and invited him to visit their place again.

The family members of Rashid Bhai and Anant were so mixed up in a few days that on the day of travel, tears could be seen in all eyes. Yunus Bhai and Mohammad Hussain accompanied Anant to the airport. Luckily, they met with a Sikh co-passenger going to Punjab State in India by the same flight. Yunus handed Anant over to him. He said that his home in Punjab is ahead of Anant’s city and he would drop Anant at his railway station or bus station depending on the mode of conveyance they would be travelling in from Delhi.

Anant arrived at his city. He decided to walk down the distance although it took twenty to twenty-five minutes to reach his home. While he was walking, Gaurav, one of his friends saw him and he gave preference to run to inform Anant’s mother rather to first meet him.

Many persons on way knew Anant. Though he was in a hurry to meet his mother yet it was natural to talk or wave to the persons who called him or with whom made the eye contacts. As such, it took about forty to forty-five minutes for Anant to reach his home. Till that time, many women, men and children with smile on their faces, assembled in front of his home. By chance, Rajni’s brother and sister-in-law had come to meet Rajni a day ago and on much persuasion by her, they had stopped with her for a day more.

Don’t know who among Anant’s friends called a drummer. All friends garlanded him and doing Bhangra dance took him to his home.

On the entrance stood Rajni in a beautiful saree carrying in her hands an Aarti plate. Anant, surrounded by friends, had reached. Mother performed son’s Aarti. Eyes of both were shedding like rivers. Rajni embraced Anant tight; both were sobbing bitterly. Nobody stopped them.

Suddenly, cries of Rajni changed into loud laughter. She started doing abnormal acts. She would have picked up a stick to beat Anant but the next moment kissed him, and then began crying abruptly.

Her brother felt her condition not well. Leaving all other things aside, he along with Anant took Rajni to the biggest hospital in the city. The doctors, after checking, disclosed that she had gone mad.

And Rajni was admitted to the hospital.

नाटक

(संकलक: धीमान पी आर)

(संकलक को इस नाटक की सामग्री अपने एक मित्र से हिन्दी भाषा में अव्यस्थित रूप में व्हाट्सएप संदेश से प्राप्त हुई थी। उसकी इसे एक दृश्य रूपी नाटक के रूप में लिखने में रुचि जागृत हुई, अतः यह प्रस्तुतीकरण ज्ञानी पाठकों के समक्ष है) 

परिचय: ऐसा विश्वास किया जाता है कि इस नाटक का संबंध संस्कृत भाषा के महान कवि, नाटककार तथा विद्वान कालिदास से है। वह 375 से 415 ई. तक ‘भारत का स्वर्णकाल’ के नाम से जाने वाले काल में गुप्त वंश के सम्राट चन्द्रगुप्त द्वितीय के दरबार में एक रत्न के रूप में प्रतिष्ठित थे।

कालिदास ने काव्य में बहुत से नाटक लिखे, जिनमें उनके ‘मेघदूत’, ‘कुमारसंभव’, ‘रघुवंश’ तथा ‘अभिज्ञान शाकुंतलम्’ को प्रसिद्ध कृतियाँ माना जाता है।

उनकी सुंदर व विख्यात रचनाएं उन्हें अहंकार के स्तर पर ले गई, और इस नाटक का संकलन उसी संदर्भ में किया गया है।

दृश्य

(कालिदास घोड़े की पीठ पर बैठकर लंबी यात्रा करते दिखते हैं। उन्हें बहुत प्यास लगी है परंतु कहीं जल नहीं दिखाई दे रहा है)

कालिदास:   ओह! यह प्यास तो मेरी जान ले लेगी पर मुझे कहीं जल नहीं मिल रहा है। सम्राट को मेरे गंतव्य तक कुछ स्थानों पर पेयजल का प्रबंध अवश्य करना चाहिए था।(अकस्मात उसे कुछ दूरी पर एक गाँव के बाहर एक वृद्धा अपने घर की आवश्यताओं हेतु कुएं से जल निकाल कर बर्तन भरती दिखाई देती है, उसने चैन की श्वास ली)

कालिदास:   हे परमात्मा! अंत में मुझ कुएं से जल भरती एक महिला दिखाई दी। मैं वहाँ जाता हूँ और अपनी प्यास बुझाने हेतु कुछ जल माँगता हूँ। मैं उससे भविष्य की आवश्यकता हेतु कुछ और जल की भी मांग करूंगा। पर वह अनपढ़ दिखाई देती है, मेरी उच्च स्थिति के बारे में नहीं समझ पाएगी, अतः उसके समक्ष मैं अपनी पहचान प्रकट नहीं करूंगा। (उस स्थान पर पहुँच कर वह घोड़े की पीठ से उतरता है, और वृद्धा के पास जाता है।

कालिदास:  माते! मैं बहुत प्यासा हूँ, प्यास के मारे मेरी जान निकली जा रही है। कृपया मुझे जल पिला दीजिए, आपका बड़ा पुण्य होगा।

महिला:    मैं आपको जल अवश्य दूँगी परंतु मैं आपको जानती नहीं, अतः पहले अपना परिचय दीजिए।

कालिदास:   मैं यात्री हूँ माता, अब मुझे जल दे दीजिए।

महिला:    आप सत्य नहीं बोल रहे हैं। आप यात्री नहीं हो सकते, क्योंकि विश्व में केवल दो ही यात्री हैं – पृथ्वी और ग्रह – जो सदैव चलते रहते हैं और कभी एक क्षण के लिए भी नहीं रुकते। सत्य बताओ, आप कौन हैं?

कालिदास: मैं अतिथि हूँ, अब मेरी प्यास बुझा दीजिए।

महिला:    नहीं, आप अतिथि भी नहीं हो सकते। अतिथि तो केवल दो ही हैं, एक युवावस्था और दूसरी संपत्ति। वे आती हैं किन्तु कुछ समय पश्चात लौट जाती हैं। अतः आप अभी भी असत्य बोल रहे हैं।

        (कालिदास ने स्वयं को महिला की तुलना में बहुत तुच्छ अनुभव किया और उसे निराशा ने घेर लिया। पर उसे जल की अपरिहार्यता थी, अतः उत्तर दिया)

कालिदास:   मैं सहनशील हूँ।

महिला:     आप पुनः असत्य बोल रहे हैं! सृष्टि में केवल दो ही सहनशील हैं – पृथ्वी एवं वृक्ष। पृथ्वी सब पापियों और पुण्यात्माओं का भार सहने में बुरा नहीं मनाती। बीज बोने के लिए उसका वक्ष चीरा जाता है, तो भी वह हर्षपूर्वक अन्न, फल, सब्जियाँ, औषधियाँ और वस्त्र देती है। यदि वृक्षों की बात करें तो यद्यपि आप उन्हें पत्थर मारें तो भी वह आपको फल, सब्जियों समेत अनेक पदार्थ देते हैं।

           (उत्तर देने में असमर्थ, कालिदास की शक्ति लगभग क्षीण हो चुकी थी और वह व्याकुलता अनुभव कर रहा था। अनजाने में उसने बोल दिया, “मैं जिद्दी हूँ”।

महिला:     तुम अभी भी सत्य नहीं बोल रहे हो। जिद्दी तो केवल दो ही हैं – नख और केश। उन्हें चाहे जितना भी काटो, पुनः उग आते हैं। आप कौन हैं?

कालिदास:   तब तो मैं मूर्ख हूँ।

महिला:     नहीं, तुम मूर्ख भी नहीं हो सकते। मूर्ख भी दो ही हैं – एक वह राजा , जो योग्य न होते हुए भी लोगों पर शासन करता है; और दूसरा, राजा के दरबार में वह विद्वान, जो चीजों की गलत व्याख्या कर राजा को खुश रखने का प्रयास करता है।

           (उत्तर न दे पाने की स्थिति में कालिदास महिला के चरणों मे गिर पड़ता है और दुखी हो रोने लगता है। कुछ क्षण पश्चात, कोई उसे हाथों से पकड़ता है और उठने के लिए कहता है)।

आवाज़     उठो पुत्र।

     (कालिदास ऊपर की ओर देखता है और अभय मुद्रा में निज श्रीचरणों से कमल-पुष्प को सुशोभित करती, बुद्धि; सत्य, कला, तथा संगीत की देवी माँ सरस्वती के दर्शन करता है। माता के एक हाथ में पुस्तक है जो बुद्धि एवं निरंतर सीखने की द्योतक है; दूसरे हाथ में सुमिरनी सुशोभित है, तथा अन्य दो करों में मस्तिष्क व देह में सामंजस्य स्थापना का प्रतीक तंत्री वाद्य-यंत्र, वीणा विराजमान है। कालिदास आदर सहित पुनः माता के चरणों मे शीश झुकाते हैं।

माता:      उठो पुत्र और मेरी बात सुनो। शिक्षा से हमें बुद्धिमता मिलती है, न कि अहंकार। तुमने शिक्षा के बल पर प्राप्त आदर व प्रतिष्ठा को अपनी अंतिम प्राप्ति मान लिया, बुद्धिमता का महत्व भूल गए और अहंकारी बन गए। अतः तुम्हें सत्य से आलोकित करने हेतु मुझे यह अभिनय करना पड़ा।

कालिदास  (हाथ जोड़कर) – मुझे क्षमा कर दें माते! आपने मेरे चक्षु व मस्तिष्क दोनों खोल दिए हैं, मैं इसके पश्चात सदैव ज्ञान ग्रहण करने की पिपासा एवम् स्वयं को विनम्र रखने में कोई कसर नहीं उठा रखूँगा।

  (माँ सरस्वती अंतर्ध्यान हो जाती हैं)।

(पटाक्षेप)

(समाप्त)

___ 

ATTAINMENT

(Play)

(Compiler: DHIMAN PR)

(A translation of the play ‘uplabdhi’ in Hindi language)

(The text of this play was received by the compiler from a friend in Hindi language on daily WhatsApp messages in a haphazard manner. He found it interesting to be re-written in the form of a short one-scene play, so this play is before the wise readers)

Introduction: The play is believed to be related to the Great Indian poet, dramatist and a scholar in Sanskrit language, KALIDASA. He was one of the gems in the court of Emperor Chandragupta-II, reigned between 375 CE to 415 CE, in Gupta dynasty known as the Golden period of India.

Kalidasa authored many dramas in poetry, and his ‘Meghduta’, ‘Kumarasambhava’, ‘Raghuvamsa’ and “Abhigyan Shakuntlam’ are considered his most famous works.        

His beautiful and prominent compositions led him to the level of arrogance, and this drama is all about that.

SCENE

(Curtain opens)

(Kalidasa is seen to be travelling on the back of a horse for a long journey. He was very thirsty but was not getting water).

Kalidasa:      Oh! This thirst will take my life but I am not getting water. The emperor must have made arrangements of drinking water at some places on way to my destination.

(Suddenly, he sees from a distance an elderly woman drawing water from a well and filling her utensils for household needs at the outskirts of a village. He sighed a sense of relief).

Kalidasa:      Oh my God! I can at last see a woman drawing water from a well. Let me go there and ask for some water to quench my thirst. I’ll also request her to give some more water for my future needs. But I will not disclose my identity before her for she looks to be an uneducated woman not able to understand my high position.

(On reaching the spot and coming down from the back of the horse, he reaches the woman)

Kalidasa:      Mother! I am very thirsty and about to die because of thirst. Kindly give me some water to drink, and that will be yours highly virtuous act.

Woman:       I’ll give you water to drink but I don’t know who you are, so first introduce yourself.

Kalidasa:      I am a traveler, mother, now give me some water.

Woman:       You are not speaking the truth. You can’t be a traveler, as there are only two travelers in the world – Earth and other Planets, who always travel and don’t stop even for a moment. Tell truly, who are you?

Kalidasa:      I am a guest, now please quench my thirst.

Woman:       No, you can’t be a guest too. There are only two guests, one youth and the other wealth. They come but go back after sometime. So, you are still lying.

(Kalidasa felt himself to be much inferior to the woman and got frustrated. But he needed water very badly, so replied) 

Kalidasa:      I am a tolerant.

Woman:       Lied again! There are only two tolerant in the world – Earth and Tree. Earth does not mind to bear the load of all including the sinners and the virtuous souls. It cheerly gives grains, fruits, vegetables, medicines and clothing produced by sowing seeds after chopping its chest. As regards the trees, they give you many things including fruits and vegetables even if you throw stones on them. So, tell truly who are you?

                     (Having no reply, Kalidasa was about to lose all his strength and got fretted. Unmindfully, he said)

Kalidasa:      I am an obstinate.

Woman:       Still not speaking truth. There are two obstinate - ‘nails’ and ‘hair’. Cut them as much times but they grow again. Who are you?

                     (Kalidasa was completely humiliated and defeated).

Kalidasa:      Then I am a stupid.

Woman:       No, you can’t be stupid too. There are only two stupid – First, that king who not having been fit rule the people; and the other is that learned person in the court of the king who tries to keep him happy even by wrong deciphering of a matter.

                     (Having no reply, Kalidasa fell into the feet of the woman and began to cry in grief. After a few moments, someone got him by arms and said to stand up).

Voice:           Stand up my son.

                     (Kalidasa looked up and saw the Goddess of wisdom, truth, art and music, Maa Saraswati seating, in the gesture of fearlessness, on a lotus flower holding in one hand a book representing the wisdom and constant learning; prayer beads in the other hand; and a Veena, a stringed instrument representing the tuning of one’s mind and body into harmony in the other two hands. Kalidasa again bowed his head into the mother’s feet in reverence).

Mother:         Get up my son and listen. Education leads one to wisdom, and not arrogance. You took your honor and prestige got on the basis of education as your final attainment, forgot the importance of wisdom, and became arrogant. As such, I had to do all this drama to enlighten you with the fact.

Kalidasa:      With folded hands, Pardon me, Mother! You have opened my eyes and mind, and now onwards, I’ll leave no stone unturned to be always thirsty for wisdom by keeping myself humble and polite. 

(Mother Saraswati disappeared).

(Curtain drops).
